Award.AwardTitle: UTeach Noyce Scholarships and Stipends: Making Teachers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, the University of Texas at Austin will continue to prepare secondary science and mathematics teachers through the project, UTeach Noyce scholarships and Stipends: Making Teachers. This Phase 2 project will support 24 juniors/seniors/post-baccalaureate students who are majoring in mathematics, computer science, or a science discipline (or who have completed such a major) and preparing to teach secondary mathematics or science in a high-need district. Each Noyce Scholar will receive up to 2 years of scholarship support. New in this Phase 2 project will be an emphasis on Maker Movement features, including having students make things they might ordinarily buy, such as electronic circuits built from components or utensils created by a 3-d printer.

Using systematic observations, surveys, and test scores, the project will address research questions such as: (1) How well do the qualifications used to select Noyce Scholars correlate with their teaching practices in their first two years? (2) Which student attributes and dispositions on entering a UTeach program are most predictive of deciding to teach? (3a) Does introduction of a Maker Education strand into teacher preparation coursework influence engagement and retention of teacher preparation candidates? (3b) Does introduction of a Maker Education strand into teacher preparation coursework lead to measurable changes in teaching practices in early years of teaching? (4) How do learning gains of high school students in Algebra and Biology whose teachers have three years of experience or less depend on the teacher's preparation route?

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project had two major goals contributing to broad impact. The first was to distribute scholarships and stipends to preservice postbaccalauretate and undergraduate teachers in the UTeach program at Austin. The second was to develop a Maker strand in the UTeach curriculum, and to explore the possibilities of drawing on the Maker movement to improve the UTeach educational program.

When the grant closed in Spring 2020 we had given Noyce scholarships and stipends to 35 individuals. Of these, 23 were undergraduates pursuing certification, and the remaining 12 were degree holders. So far 21 have completed certification and are currently teaching or have accepted a position.  Of the remaining, 8 have not yet completed the program, 3 are recent graduates seeking employment, and the final 3 are currently in non-teaching jobs.

It is a strong and diverse group of students. 24 are women, and 37% come from under-represented groups; less than 8% are white males. The mean GPA is 3.43, and three of the students have maintained a 4.0 GPA.

The UTeach Maker program we developed is a selective micro-credentialing program that supports the best and brightest UTeach students interested in bringing innovative practices and skills into their STEM classroom. UTeach Makers learn to construct physical artifacts with tools such as 3-d printers, and they learn how to teach the skills of Making to their own students.  23 UTeach students completed the Maker micro-credential by the end of Fall 2019. 

Not only did we initiaite UTeach Maker in Austin, we created a national network of universities taking part of the UTeach Make for All Initiative. 22 universities are members as of Spring 2020.

We also investigated several questions contributing to intellectual merit of the project.

We wanted to know what attribute of a student at the beginning of our Noyce-supported teacher preparation program was most predictive of eventually teaching. We addressed this through surveys of program participants at the begining of the program and tracking them into teaching. The answer was that teaching experience prior to entering our program was the best predictor, even a better predictor than declaring a desire to teach.

We wanted to know whether introduction of the Maker microcredential would influence teaching practices of our graduates in their first years. We investigated this by conducting detailed observations of class sessions for four of our the program graduates, coupled with interviews. The teachers did incorporate Making into their teaching and found that it motivated and energized their students. The teachers varied in the frequency with which they employed these methods, and they also experienced variation in the degree of acceptance by other teachers and administrators in the schools.

We wanted to know whether student learning in Algebra I and Biology classrooms is greater when the teacher comes from a university program as opposed to alternative certification. We addressed this by conducting value-added studies using a large dataset of educational outcomes in Texas. We found two advantages for mathematics and science teachers prepared in the standard way in Texas. First, since 2008 they  stayed in the classroom longer than those who pursued alternative routes. Second, we analyzed student performance on Algebra 1 and Biology exams over the period 2012-2018. Algebra I students with experienced teachers from standard programs gained .03 to .05 in standard deviation units compared to students whose teachers were alternatively prepared. For Biology students there were fewer statistically significant differences, but when differences existed they almost all favored students of teachers from standard programs.

Modified by: Michael P Marder
